Subject: Node Bloat
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=ShUhuYzRMWwQPtV78X8_e7XwuQsO5qvNsQuYqf4Bs0ecGU8fhcgn
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello all-

I don't work in GP, but I have been told that those trees bloat (evolve to
have many, many internal nodes that are mostly non-functional). I have also
heard, though don't know if it is true, that the main reason for bloat is
because the trees are trying to lower their effective mutation rate (if 1%
of nodes get mutated, and there are more nodes, the good one are less likely
to be affected by mutation).

Do you guys generally see this happen in NEAT? Do the networks get
ridiculously large when smaller networks would do?

I notice in HyperNEAT that the config files used in the papers typically
only have an add node mutation rate operator (the demolish node probability
is set to zero). This seems to me like it would add to the upward pressure
to create bloated networks.

In most of my experiments so far with HyperNEAT (like the ones in the paper
I recently posted here), the CPPN networks did not explode in size, which
surprised me. However, in some new experiments I am doing I am seeing the
networks get large (e.g. ~200 nodes). This is happening even when I make the
demolishNode probability the same as the addNode probability.

If you are seeing bloat, how do you combat it? Do you generally have to set
the demolishNode prop to be much higher than addNode? Or do you give a
fitness penalty for larger networks?





Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...
